text:
Q: How to optimize enum size? A:

The first thing to note is that this sort of enum couldn't possibly be stored in just 16 bytes, given the current definition of Pc and assuming 8-byte usize. The reason is that the Split(Pc, Pc) possibility takes up all possible 16-byte bit patterns on its own (because any such pattern can be interpreted as two usizes), so there would be no room for the other possibilities.

If the enum is going to take up more than 16 bytes, it would need to take up 24 bytes for alignment reasons. The issue is that many processors can't efficiently read numbers from memory unless their address is a multiple of the number's size; for example, 64-bit processors might not be able to read a usize unless its address is a multiple of 8. This means that if you decided to store many enum Insts in an array or vector, the address of each element must be a multiple of 8, so the distance between the elements must also be a multiple of 8, and thus their size when placed in an array must be a multiple of 8. If it's a multiple of 8, and larger than 16, it must be at least 24. (Some languages have an optimization to allow for types to be smaller when handled outside an array than when placed inside an array, but Rust doesn't – it simplifies things by ensuring that any given type always has a single representation, at least within a single compile.)

One other thing to be aware of is that Rust's enum layout optimisations only cover a particular set of cases. At the time of writing, an enum like this (slightly modified from yours) is also 24 bytes:

type Pc = usize;

pub enum Inst {
    Char(Pc, char),
    Range(Pc, char, char),
    Any(Pc),
    Split(Pc, u32),
    Jump(Pc),
    Match,
}

This is despite the fact that this enum trivially could be stored in 16 bytes (e.g. by storing the fields in order and the discriminant at the end). It isn't at present simply because the Rust compiler doesn't have a case for optimising this sort of enum – the current enum optimizations are all based on "niches" (Rust describes types as having a "niche" if they don't use all the possible bit patterns that would fit into their size, e.g. NonZeroUsize doesn't use all-bits-zero), whereas there are no niches in any of the types stored in the enum and thus no optimizations are attempted (and a naive layout algorithm gives a size of 24 bytes because it sees Range and Split as "16 bytes" due to alignment rounding).

It's possible that Rust will add more enum optimizations in the future – the exact layout of enums mostly isn't a stable part of the language (with a few specific exceptions like #[repr(C)] and Option<Box<T>> which don't help here), and it's one of those parts of the language which was intentionally left open for future optimisations. So it's possible that my example enum will be 16 bytes in the future. But the enum that you gave originally does have to be at least 24 bytes in order to work under Rust's sizing assumptions.

If you're looking to make the enum smaller, there are two main tricks you can use. One is to use types with niches in order to provide optimization opportunities, but it won't help in this case: for example, if you make Pc into NonZeroUsize, there still isn't enough room to fit all the enum cases into 16 bytes (in theory, Split could be stored as (Pc, Pc), Any as (Pc, 0), Jump as (0, Pc), and Match as (0, 0), but that still leaves Char and Range unaccounted for). Note that Rust won't optimize enums in this sort of complicated way anyway, because it causes runtime performance issues (if you're doing a complicated matrix of cases like this, you have to read too much of the enum to figure out what its discriminant is) – so even with NonZeroUsize and without Char and Range, Rust wouldn't optimize your particular enum. In order to make it work, you would have to use types with bigger niches (i.e. fewer valid representations) – but as of right now, there are few such types in stable Rust, and the ones that are (such as char which can't represent values above 0x10FFFF, and &[T] which can't represent lengths above isize::MAX) aren't really useful in solving the problem you have.

The other approach is to store some of the data out of line by using Box, e.g. by replacing Split(Pc, Pc) with Split(Box<(Pc, Pc)>). This is often a helpful technique in cases where one or two of the variants are much larger than the others (especially if they're rarely used). However, it won't help in this case because your variants are too similar in size (and not that much larger than Box anyway). In theory, Split(Box<(Pc, Pc)>) might be able to get down to 16 bytes if Rust optimized perfectly, but as in my example above, Rust currently doesn't have an optimization for this case so doing this in present Rust won't reduce the enum below 24 bytes.

Q: How to disable AI autocomplete in VS Code? A:

You can do so by using shift+p and looking for copilot disable

Q: How does "Hello World" work in Shakespeare Programming Language? A:

I believe that your code is a bit wrong. Here is the Hello World code in Shakespeare Programming Langauge:

The tempestuous ocean.
Romeo, a young man with remarkable patience.
Juliet, a likewise young woman of remarkable grace.

Act I: The setup.
Scene I: The beginning.
[Exeunt]

Act II: Printing "Hello, World!"
Scene I: Setup for printing.
Romeo: Listen to thy heart!

Scene II: The printing loop.
Juliet: Am I better than you? If not, let us proceed to scene III.
Romeo: Open your heart.

Scene III: Print the character.
Juliet: Open your heart.
Romeo: Is the quotient between the sum of a big big big big big big big big big big big big big big big big big big big big big big big big big big big big big number and a big big big big big big big big big big big big big big big big big big big big big big big big big big big big big number and a big big big big big big big big big big big big big big big big big big big big big big big big big big big big big number nicer than the sum of yourself and a big big big big big big big big big big big big big big big big big big big big big big big big big big big big big number? If so, let us proceed to scene IV.
Juliet: Speak your mind!

Scene IV: Repeat the printing loop.
Romeo: Open your mind.

Scene V: Done printing.
[Exeunt]

And here is the explanation to that code:

The play starts with "The tempestuous ocean," which is just a placeholder to indicate the beginning. "Romeo" and "Juliet" are characters used to represent variables. Acts and scenes are used to structure the program. In Act I, Scene I, [Exeunt] indicates the end of the setup. Act II, Scene I, sets up the printing process. Act II, Scene II, is a loop where Juliet questions Romeo's worthiness. The loop continues until a condition is met. Act II, Scene III, prints characters based on a complex condition involving arithmetic operations. Act II, Scene IV, continues the loop. Act II, Scene V, indicates the end of printing. The program concludes.
